awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Nitrate Radicals and Biogenic Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs):  Oxidation, Mechanisms and Organic Aerosol; Atlanta, GA; June 22-24, 2015
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports a small workshop that will provide opportunities for participants to discuss current research, address key outstanding questions, and stimulate future research ideas on the role of nitrate radical chemistry in the formation of small particles in the atmosphere in regions where there are emissions of volatile organics from the biosphere.  A deeper understanding of this chemistry will provide improved constraints on model predictions of aerosol formation and their effects on climate and air quality.

The workshop will involve researchers with expertise in laboratory, field, and modeling together to identify laboratory studies (e.g., kinetics, mechanisms, products, etc.) to obtain a deeper understanding of the chemical interactions between biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOC) and nitrate radicals (NO3). The workshop will include early-career scientists and established scientists, as well as a number of younger researchers (post docs and students).

The expected results of the workshop are: (1) a review paper on BVOC+NO3 chemistry; (2) a list of key scientific questions to be addressed and directions for future fundamental studies on the oxidation of BVOCs with nitrate radicals; (3) a list of critical measurements and types of studies (e.g., chamber experiments, flow tube studies, wet chemistry, etc.) needed to address the key scientific questions; (4) collaborative research proposals that may be submitted to various funding agencies; and (5) the publication of new findings on key scientific topics identified at the workshop in a special issue in Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics.

por.por_cntn:
A workshop on “Nitrate Radicals and Biogenic Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs): Oxidation, Mechanisms and Organic Aerosol” was held at the Georgia Institute of Technology (Atlanta, USA) on June 22-24, 2015. The workshop was initiated with support from International Global Atmospheric Chemistry (IGAC) as part of the IGAC activity on Fundamentals of Atmospheric Chemistry.

 

The reaction between BVOC and nitrate radicals (NO3) represents a direct mechanism linking anthropogenic and biogenic emissions. However, the extent to which this affects aerosol formation is poorly understood. The goals of the workshop were 1) To provide a forum for participants interested in nitrate radical oxidation to discuss current research, address key outstanding questions and stimulate future research ideas; 2) To bring researchers with expertise in laboratory, field and modeling together to identify laboratory studies to obtain a deeper understanding of BVOC+NO3 chemistry.

 

Thirty researchers from six countries participated in the workshop, representing academic research, national laboratories and government agencies, including the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). The workshop was comprised of keynote presentations, presentations from participants, facilitated discussions and breakout sessions.

 

A review paper has been published based on the discussions at the workshop (Ng, Brown et al., ACP, 2017). The article reviews the current literature in several areas relevant to the understanding of BVOC+NO3 chemistry, with a particular focus on recent advances in instrumentation and atmospheric model development, as well as in organic nitrate and secondary organic aerosol (SOA) formation. It outlines perspectives on the implications of this chemistry for understanding climate and air quality, its response to current emission trends and its relevance to implementation of control strategies. It also identifies critical research needs for analytical methods, models, and issues to address in future laboratory studies and ambient field measurements. The review concludes with an assessment of the impacts of BVOC+NO3 reactions on air quality, visibility, and climate.

 

The workshop provided impetus for the broader atmospheric chemistry community to address key scientific questions and directions for future studies on this research topic. Building on the success of the workshop, we have:

 

1. Organized a Town Hall meeting at the 2016 American Geophysical Union (AGU) fall meeting on “Nitrate Radicals and Biogenic Volatile Organic Compounds and Anthropogenic - Biogenic Interactions”.

 

2. Organized a special symposium at the 2016 American Association for Aerosol Research (AAAR) annual conference on “Effects of NOx and SO2 on BVOC Oxidation and Organic Aerosol Formation”.

 

The broader impact of the workshop occurred at a number of levels. The in-depth discussions at the workshop and subsequent meetings (AGU, AAAR) opened up new research directions and have a positive, synergistic effect on the efficiency and research progress in this topic. This has facilitated new and continued effort to understand the effects of NOx on aerosol formation and their climate and health impacts. The workshop brought together senior and junior scientists, which provided networking and career development opportunities for the younger scientists.

 

Details and program of the workshop are available at this website:

http://www.atmosphere.eas.gatech.edu/no3workshop/

 

Review paper can be downloaded here:

http://www.atmos-chem-phys.net/17/2103/2017/
